node.title: Germany will again offer free Covid tests to all adults.
node.description: Officials hope that identifying infections earlier can help stop a recent surge in cases.

node.title: Despite Critical Race Theory Outrage, Majority of GOP Voters Want History of Racism Taught
node.description: More than half of all Republicans back public school teachers teaching students "the history of racism," according to a poll released Wednesday.

node.title: Anger Over Kyle Rittenhouse Trial Judge Grows After Week of Controversies
node.description: Kenosha County Circuit Judge Bruce Schroeder has been accused of making racist jokes and being biased towards the 18-year-old defendant.

node.title: Teddy lost in Glacier National Park returned to six-year-old girl
node.description: Sharp-eyed ranger spotted it in melting snow and used it in his truck as a mascot – until he learned its history. Many people came together to facilitate the return.

node.title: Murkowski announces she's running for reelection
node.description: Senator Lisa Murkowsi was among the Republicans who voted to convict former President Trump in his second impeachment trial.

node.title: What Should We Do With Robert Smithson and Nancy Holt’s Island?
node.description: In the 1970s, the artists bought a rocky strip of land off the coast of Maine. Now, it’s a place for others to wrestle with their legacies.

node.title: Athletes in a Ravaged Louisiana Town Try to Run Back to Normalcy
node.description: Hurricane Ida knocked down much of Grand Isle, La., but the town’s cross-country team is determined to compete in the state championship meet.

node.title: The Pursuit of Perfection
node.description: Barcelona Femení is the champion of Spain and Europe, and perhaps the most dominant club team in the world. The team’s coach and his players expect it to be better.

node.title: Woman Accuses Vikings’ Dalvin Cook of Assault, False Imprisonment in Lawsuit
node.description: Cook on Wednesday denied the allegations made by his former girlfriend in a civil suit that stemmed from a confrontation at his home in November 2020.

node.title: The Many Deaths of William Holden Taught Me How to Be Anxious
node.description: My father’s tales kept me safe.

node.title: For a 96-Year-Old Veteran, the Parade Came to Him
node.description: Jack Le Vine, usually spends the holiday doing “nothing.” His Brooklyn neighbors had other plans.

node.title: The Show Goes On, Even After China Tried to Shut It Down
node.description: An Italian city rejected a request from the Chinese Embassy in Rome to cancel an exhibition by Badiucao, an artist who has been described as the Chinese Banksy.

node.title: Majority of Millennials Would Change Job to Spend More Time With Their Pet
node.description: New research has shown how pet owners have grown close to their four-legged friends during the pandemic.

node.title: Key goals unmet with COP26 climate change summit down to final hours
node.description: On the final day of the United Nations climate conference, there was no indication that nations would agree to emissions cuts needed to limit global warming, or to help poor countries deal with its impact.

node.title: Sex assault threat among hazing allegations vs. top N.J. school team
node.description: A semifinal football playoff game involving Wall Township High School has been canceled and some school employees suspended as authorities conduct an investigation.

node.title: Defense rests its case at trial of Kyle Rittenhouse
node.description: Closing arguments are expected to begin on Monday — both parties will have two and a half hours each for arguments and rebuttals.

node.title: Blizzard warnings, winter weather advisories in Midwest - and more top stories
node.description: The latest national headlines from CBS News.

node.title: An Artist Who Disavows the Possibility of Individual Agency
node.description: According to Agnieszka Kurant, everything we make — from the systems that oppress us to the inventions that transform us — is the result of a collective.

node.title: Johnson & Johnson will break itself up into two.
node.description: The corporate giant said it would spin off its consumer products division, leaving the company to manufacture and market drugs and medical devices.

node.title: Police officers search the homes of four people linked to Italy’s ‘No Green Pass’ movement.
node.description: The group has staged protests for weeks over a nationwide Covid rule, often blocking traffic and access to city centers.

node.title: Massive, Colliding Black Holes May Expand Along With the Universe
node.description: The growth of massive merging black holes with masses over 40 times that of the sun could be linked with the accelerating expansion of the Universe in a "cosmological coupling."

node.title: What's in Subway's Tuna? Sandwich Chain Responds to Claims Made in Lawsuit
node.description: A suit filed in San Francisco alleges that lab tests found Subway's tuna contained other animal proteins including chicken, pork and cattle.

node.title: Are sports digital collectibles a winning investment?
node.description: Digital sports collectibles are expected to push the world of non-fungible tokens into a $75 billion market by 2025.

node.title: Auschwitz Survivor Shows Off Camp Tattoo, Telling Doctor 'I Understand Risk'
node.description: A woman who survived the Auschwitz concentration camp as a child showed a doctor the tattoo of her serial number, as they discussed the risks of an operation.

node.title: Child Tax Credit 2021: Here's when the fifth check will deposit
node.description: After the November 15 payment, there's only one check remaining — unless lawmakers renew the benefit.

node.title: "We don't want any more Black pastors" in Arbery murder trial, lawyer says
node.description: The Rev. Al Sharpton said his attendance in the courtroom was "not disruptive in any way" and was "at the invitation of the family."

node.title: Aiming for ‘zero Covid,’ China focuses on frozen food, children’s clothes and, soon, the Olympics.
node.description: The Communist Party is making broad efforts to stamp out the disease entirely, but the measures come with costs.

node.title: 'Exhausted' Antarctic Penguin Rescued After 1,900-Mile Swim to New Zealand
node.description: Walkers found the lost and tired-looking animal, which has been relocated to a beach with fewer predators in the hopes it will swim home.

node.title: Russia Promises It Won't Invade Ukraine, Despite Troop Buildup at Border
node.description: Russia's deputy U.N. ambassador pushed back against reports of a possible military invasion of Ukraine, following criticism from the U.S. over a troop buildup at Ukraine's border.

node.title: Second COP26 draft agreement softens language on coal and fossil fuel reduction
node.description: The draft decision, the second released this week, is being negotiated by representatives from nearly 200 countries and the final version has to be agreed to by all countries at the summit

node.title: The Netherlands plans a partial lockdown regardless of vaccination status.
node.description: The country is experiencing rising case numbers amid a fourth wave of infections.

node.title: How Does This End?
node.description: Thinking about Covid and normalcy.

node.title: Texas Cheerleader Makayla Noble 'Instantly' Knew She Was Paralyzed in Accident
node.description: After several weeks of rehabilitation, the 17-year-old can now lift her arms and also has feeling in her legs.

node.title: U.S., EU Risk Losing 'Heart of Europe' to China, Montenegro Warns
node.description: Foreign Minister Dorde Radulovic told Newsweek that Podgorica wants to pivot West, but needs money to do so.

node.title: Rudy Giuliani Calls Adam Schiff 'Traitor' Who Should Be Removed From Congress
node.description: Schiff has said the House Select Committee investigating the events of January 6 is "deeply interested" in Giuliani.

node.title: N.J. teen Jashyah Moore, missing almost a month, found safe in NYC
node.description: After she vanhished, authorities pleaded for tips and raised $20,000 in reward money. Search parties were organized and some activists even blocked traffic in East Orange, N.J. to raise awareness.

node.title: NPR's Tim Mak on the NRA's troubles — "The Takeout"
node.description: On "The Takeout" podcast this week, host Major Garrett talks with Mak about his new book, which contains allegations of corruption at the top of the NRA.

node.title: LG WT7900HBA and LG DLEX7900BE Review: Impressive Washer and Dryer Pair
node.description: The LG WT7900HBA washer and LG DLEX7900BE dryer deliver impressive features, great cleaning capabilities and a smart door design that we can't believe we lived without.

node.title: Jones Tries to Block Ryan's Visit Through Guyana Pressure
node.description: Jim Jones used various women to influence Guyanese officials - could they block Leo Ryan's visit?

node.title: Donald Trump Endorses Matt Maddock, Tells Him 'You Have a Great Wife'
node.description: The state representative and his wife Meshawn, who is co-chair of the Michigan Republican Party, have both promoted the false claim that the 2020 election was rigged.

node.title: For Some South Africans, de Klerk Missed Chances for True Reconciliation
node.description: The last white president of South Africa helped bring an end to the apartheid regime, but for many citizens, he never went far enough to disavow it. He left a video apologizing.

node.title: RJ's licorice recalled after using contaminated sugar
node.description: Confectionary brand RJ's has been affected by a recent major recall of sugar, leading to it issuing its own recall of licorice.

node.title: For Arab Americans, It’s Not Thanksgiving Without Hashweh
node.description: The rice-based stuffing is often a centerpiece of celebrations in the Arab world, and on holiday tables in the United States.

node.title: James Baldwin’s Review, Babe Ruth and Other Letters to the Editor
node.description: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.

node.title: Hong Kong Broadcaster’s Swift Turn From Maverick Voice to Official Mouthpiece
node.description: RTHK has often set the news agenda with its aggressive coverage of the city. But a Beijing clampdown has changed that, with pro-China coverage filling the void.

node.title: University Bomb Threats: Full List of Every College Targeted Across America
node.description: "Our police department is working closely with the FBI to identify what appears to be a pattern...but at this point, it's hard to tell," said New Haven Mayor Justin Elicker.

node.title: Their Romance Blossomed from a Love of Plants
node.description: Dr. Sarah Santucci and Kevin Zhang met in 2013 at Princeton. She had impressed him with her knowledge of plants.

node.title: He Wanted the Relationship More Than the Job
node.description: Shortly after Andrew Katz and Marysa Greenawalt began dating, he moved to Washington for a job. Six months later he returned to New York and Ms. Greenawalt.

node.title: He Had Many Questions Before Popping the Big One

node.title: ‘The Kiss to End All Kisses’
node.description: The actor Elisabeth Röhm and Peter Glatzer, a film producer and hotel developer, started out as friends. But their relationship changed after the pandemic hit.

node.title: The One Was Actually ‘Number 30’
node.description: After a second divorce, Petra Schaefer had committed to 100 dates, with someone different each time. Then she met Bruce Hunsaker.

node.title: They (Kind of) Have His Father to Thank for a First Date
node.description: Denrick Kimathi Cooper Jr. borrowed some cash from his dad to take Elizabeth Comer on what she called “the best first date I ever had.”

node.title: What Does It Take to Build a Disaster-Proof House?
node.description: A few homeowners across the country are trying to find out, by experimenting with new (and old) construction techniques.

node.title: Her Persistence Paid Off
node.description: Giovanni Rivera and Barbara Delgado were on the verge of breaking up when she wanted to make their relationship exclusive. But she refused to call it quits.

node.title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend

node.title: New in Paperback:
node.description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

node.title: A Singer Lends Her Voice to a Conversation About Autism

node.title: Will the Britney Spears Conservatorship End Today?

node.title: The Stakes Are Sky-High for a ‘Ring’ Coming to the Met Opera
node.description: For Richard Jones, the director of a staging that will open in London and later travel to New York, this is a third attempt at Wagner’s epic.

node.title: The 2021 New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books Winners at Work
node.description: A look at the artists behind this year’s winning books, in their studios.

node.title: Hong Kong’s M+ Museum Is Finally Open. It’s Already in Danger.
node.description: The museum, billed as Asia’s premier art institution, faced construction delays and personnel problems. Now it faces its greatest challenge: the threat of censorship.

node.title: He Stalks Delirious, Unfinished New York as It Rises
node.description: Nick Relph’s new book, “Eclipse Body & Soul Syntax,” collects years of digital street scans of New York City construction posters, an eerie portrait of a supersizing metropolis.

node.description: We invite you to take a look at this year’s winners.

node.title: More Teams Are Contenders This Women’s College Basketball Season
node.description: And some teams at the top have worked hard to get better ahead of the N.C.A.A. tournament in March.

node.title: A Nike Executive Told of Once Killing a Man. Here’s What He Left Out.
node.description: Larry Miller has written a book revealing that at age 16, in 1965, he murdered someone. The disclosure blindsided the family of the victim, whose name he never mentioned.

node.title: The Secret to a Better Internet? Post Less, Chat More.
node.description: One of the web’s oldest functions remains one of its most powerful and promising.

node.title: Madison Saw Something in the Constitution We Should Open Our Eyes To
node.description: The guarantee clause could help Democrats push back against the threat of Republican political hegemony.

node.title: You Are the Object of a Secret Extraction Operation
node.description: Ending data extraction is the key to ending surveillance capitalism.

node.title: It’s Time for the Media to Choose: Neutrality or Democracy?
node.description: Jay Rosen on how the press fundamentally misunderstands American politics.

node.title: Sure, Biden’s Plan Costs a Lot of Money. But the Price of Inaction Is Higher.
node.description: Tell Senator Manchin that failing to deliver is more than we can afford.

node.title: 275 Minutes on Hold: Why Airline Customer Service Still Can’t Keep Up
node.description: It’s been a familiar and infuriating story during the pandemic: Hours waiting for an agent only to have the call dropped. The ordeal of rescheduling canceled flights. Delayed refunds. What gives?

node.title: Now TV Wants Nielsen to Measure Up
node.description: After years of complaints, NBCUniversal and its peers are looking for other ways to count viewers, with or without the ratings giant.

node.title: What Bosses Really Think About the Future of the Office
node.description: C.E.O.s are eager for employees to return — and afraid of alienating those who have grown accustomed to working from home.

node.title: Will Zephyr Teachout Finally Have Her Moment?
node.description: The law professor, a darling of New York’s left wing, wants to be attorney general.

node.title: How the Editor of Bon Appétit Spends Her Sundays
node.description: Dawn Davis walks her dog through Central Park and plays tennis to clear her head. And yes, she cooks, too.

node.title: On Rikers Island, a Doctor Who Tends to the Oldest and Sickest
node.description: Insights from Dr. Rachael Bedard, a jail-based geriatrician.

node.title: Saving the Forgotten Connecticut Farm That Helped Spark M.L.K.’s Dream
node.description: Summers spent working on a tobacco farm in the 1940s opened a teenage Martin Luther King Jr. to a world beyond the Jim Crow South.

node.title: Why Open a Bodega When People Will Pay $150 a Pound for Yemeni Coffee?
node.description: Second-generation Yemeni entrepreneurs in Brooklyn want to reclaim their role as the purveyors of the original specialty coffee.

node.title: Why Democrats May Have a Long Wait if They Lose Their Grip on Washington
node.description: Voters’ reflexive instinct to check the party in power makes it hard for any party to retain a hold on both the White House and Congress for long.

node.title: Black Farmworkers Say They Lost Jobs to Foreigners Who Were Paid More
node.description: Longtime field laborers in the Mississippi Delta said in a lawsuit that they were asked to train white guest workers from South Africa before losing their jobs to them.

node.title: Pick-up Artist Tom Torero Sold Sex Recordings, Targeted Teen Girls Using Major Tech Firms
node.description: Leaked footage obtained by Newsweek suggests pick-up artist Tom Torero had secretly recorded audio of himself having sex with women and sold the content.

node.title: Black Lives Matter Co-Founder Says Democrats Have 'Dragged Their Feet' on Racial Justice
node.description: BLM's Ayọ Tometi said the movement needed more power and that it had not enjoyed the kind of access to the White House people have assumed.

node.title: Out of 1.1 Million Homeland Security Threat Reports, Only 1,200 Used the Word 'Trump'
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: U.K. woman demands change after "strange" spiking at nightclub
node.description: In the last two months, police in the U.K. have received at least 56 reports of people fearing they've been stuck by needles in drugging attempts, and boycotts of clubs have taken place in cities across the country.

node.title: Beloved dolphin Winter, of "Dolphin Tale" movies, has died at 16
node.description: The prosthetic-tailed dolphin's real-life story of rehabilitation became an inspiration for disabled people around the world. It died of intestinal issues.

node.title: Aussies highlight positives from poor T20 World Cup build-up after reaching final
node.description: Australia lost five consecutive T20 series prior to the men's World Cup, but coach Justin Langer believes the experience ultimately benefited his squad.

node.title: This funnel-web spider could bite through your fingernail. Its venom will also save lives
node.description: A massive funnel-web spider with fangs so long they could bite through a human fingernail is donated to a lifesaving antivenom program at the Australian Reptile Park.

node.title: Who's on the International Space Station? Video Shows Astronauts Entering After Dragon Docks
node.description: With seven people on board, the ISS is now back to its standard capacity following a crew switchover.

node.title: Tributes Paid to Winter the Dolphin, Star of 'Dolphin Tale,' Dead at 16
node.description: The marine mammal became an inspiration when she was equipped with a prosthetic tail in 2005 after she was caught in a crab trap and it left her unable to swim.

node.title: In Ocasio-Cortez’s District, Disagreements About the Democrats’ Direction
node.description: She voted against the infrastructure bill. Now, even in her own district, she faces questions of whether she put her constituents’ interests first.

node.title: In-N-Out Burger Rejects Ron DeSantis Pitch to Move to Florida
node.description: The fast food chain got the offer after its San Francisco outlet was closed for refusing to adhere to vaccination proof rules.

node.title: Court hears alleged murder victim's house was unusually clean and smelt like bleach
node.description: The trial of Paul Winston Oatey continues in Adelaide's Supreme Court. He is accused of murdering 53-year-old Darren Perry in December 2019. The teenage girl who the court heard discovered Mr Perry's body in a backyard gives evidence.

node.title: Katherine mask mandate extended after positive COVID-19 wastewater results
node.description: A mask mandate in the town of Katherine is extended for a further 24 hours after positive wastewater results were detected in the region.

node.title: 'Not the smartest thing': Black Caps star breaks hand punching bat, ruled out of T20 World Cup final
node.description: An outburst of frustration leaves Devon Conway nursing a broken hand following New Zealand's semi-final victory over England, ruling the wicketkeeper-batter out of the tournament decider against Australia.

node.title: Shearing on at A and P show with no crowd
node.description: An oink here, a baa baa there, that's the Canty show this year as some competitiors take to the grounds with no spectators due to Covid-19.

node.title: Ocasio-Cortez Isn’t Wavering. Are New Yorkers on Her Side?
node.description: By voting no on the infrastructure bill, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez set off a fierce debate, including among city residents eager to see the subways improved.

node.title: Graeme Edge, co-founder of The Moody Blues, dies at 80
node.description: Moody Blues frontman Justin Hayward confirms Graeme Edge's death on the group's website. The cause of his death has not been revealed.

node.title: 'Daigou is dying', but Australian products remain popular in China despite trade tensions
node.description: The world's largest online shopping festival sets a new sales record, with Australian products playing a big part, but year-on-year growth falls to its slowest since the event began.

node.title: Prison Won’t Be a Riot for the QAnon Shaman, Jimmy Kimmel Says
node.description: “Prosecutors are recommending 51 months behind bars, after which, he will be remanded into the custody of ‘Dancing With the Stars,’” Kimmel joked.

node.title: Manfred achieves his dream of becoming a physicist — at age 89
node.description: Manfred Steiner, 89, decided to study physics rather than hit around golf balls after retirement — earning his PhD and inspiring others to pursue their ambitions at any age.
